name: 1598_D. Training Session
description:
Monocarp is the coach of the Berland State University programming teams. He decided to compose a problemset for a training session for his teams.

Monocarp has n problems that none of his students have seen yet. The i-th problem has a topic a_i (an integer from 1 to n) and a difficulty b_i (an integer from 1 to n). All problems are different, that is, there are no two tasks that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

Monocarp decided to select exactly 3 problems from n problems for the problemset. The problems should satisfy at least one of two conditions (possibly, both):

  * the topics of all three selected problems are different; 
  * the difficulties of all three selected problems are different. 



Your task is to determine the number of ways to select three problems for the problemset.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.
repair_prompt:
Monocarp is the coach of the Berland State University programming teams. He decided to create a set of problems for a training session for his teams.

Monocarp has n problems that none of his students have seen yet. The i-th problem has a topic a_i (an integer from 1 to n) and a difficulty b_i (an integer from 1 to n). All problems are different, that is, there are no two tasks that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

Monocarp decided to select exactly 3 problems from n problems for the problemset. The problems should satisfy at least one of two conditions (possibly, both):

  * the topics of all three selected problems are different; 
  * the difficulties of all three selected problems are different. 

Your task is to calculate the number of methods to choose three problems for the problemset. Make sure to consider edge cases where the number of problems n might be small.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.

Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp is the coach of the Berland State University programming teams and decided to create a set of problems for a training session for his teams. Monocarp has n problems that none of his students have seen yet, with topics and difficulties ranging from 1 to n, and wants to select exactly 3 problems that satisfy certain conditions. Your task is to calculate the number of methods to choose three problems for the problemset, considering edge cases where n might be small.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completions:
from itertools import combinations

def calculate_ways_to_select_problems(testcases):
    results = []
    
    for problems in testcases:
        n = problems[0]
        problems = problems[1:]
        
        possible_combinations = list(combinations(problems, 3))
        count = 0
        
        for comb in possible_combinations:
            topics = set()
            difficulties = set()
            
            for problem in comb:
                topics.add(problem[0])
                difficulties.add(problem[1])
            
            if len(topics) == 3 or len(difficulties) == 3:
                count += 1
        
        results.append(count)
    
    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    testcases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        problems = []
        
        for _ in range(n):
            a, b = map(int, input().split())
            problems.append((a, b))
        
        testcases.append([n] + problems)
    
    results = calculate_ways_to_select_problems(testcases)
    
    for result in results:
        print(result)

main()

from collections import defaultdict

def calculate_ways_to_select_problems():
    t = int(input())
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        topics = defaultdict(int)
        difficulties = defaultdict(int)
        
        for _ in range(n):
            a, b = map(int, input().split())
            topics[a] += 1
            difficulties[b] += 1
        
        total_ways = n * (n - 1) * (n - 2) // 6
        
        same_topic_difficulty = 0
        for topic in topics.values():
            same_topic_difficulty += topic * (topic - 1) * (topic - 2) // 6
        
        for difficulty in difficulties.values():
            same_topic_difficulty += difficulty * (difficulty - 1) * (difficulty - 2) // 6
        
        different_topic_difficulty = 0
        for topic in topics.values():
            different_topic_difficulty += topic * (topic - 1) // 2
        
        for difficulty in difficulties.values():
            different_topic_difficulty += difficulty * (difficulty - 1) // 2
        
        total_ways -= same_topic_difficulty + different_topic_difficulty
        
        print(total_ways)

calculate_ways_to_select_problems()

main()

from collections import defaultdict

def calculate_ways_to_select_problems():
    t = int(input())
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        topics = defaultdict(int)
        difficulties = defaultdict(int)
        
        for _ in range(n):
            a, b = map(int, input().split())
            topics[a] += 1
            difficulties[b] += 1
        
        total_ways = n * (n - 1) * (n - 2) // 6
        
        same_topic = same_difficulty = 0
        for topic in topics.values():
            same_topic += topic * (topic - 1) * (topic - 2) // 6
        for difficulty in difficulties.values():
            same_difficulty += difficulty * (difficulty - 1) * (difficulty - 2) // 6
        
        total_ways -= same_topic + same_difficulty
        
        print(total_ways)

calculate_ways_to_select_problems()

main()

from itertools import combinations

# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of problems
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the topics and difficulties of each problem
    problems = [list(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of ways to select three problems
    count = 0
    
    # Generate all combinations of 3 problems
    problem_combinations = combinations(problems, 3)
    
    # Check each combination if it meets the requirements
    for comb in problem_combinations:
        topics = set()
        difficulties = set()
        for problem in comb:
            topics.add(problem[0])
            difficulties.add(problem[1])
        if len(topics) == 3 or len(difficulties) == 3:
            count += 1
    
    # Output the result for the current testcase
    print(count)

main()

from collections import defaultdict

def calculate_ways_to_select_problems(t, testcases):
    def count_unique_topics_difficulties(problems):
        topics = defaultdict(int)
        difficulties = defaultdict(int)
        for topic, difficulty in problems:
            topics[topic] += 1
            difficulties[difficulty] += 1
        return topics, difficulties

    def calculate_combinations(n):
        return n * (n - 1) * (n - 2) // 6

    results = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = testcases[_][0]
        problems = testcases[_][1:]
        topics, difficulties = count_unique_topics_difficulties(problems)

        unique_topics = sum(1 for topic in topics if topics[topic] >= 1)
        unique_difficulties = sum(1 for difficulty in difficulties if difficulties[difficulty] >= 1)

        if unique_topics >= 3 or unique_difficulties >= 3:
            results.append(calculate_combinations(n))
        else:
            results.append(0)

    return results

if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    testcases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        problems = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]
        testcases.append([n] + problems)

    results = calculate_ways_to_select_problems(t, testcases)

    for result in results:
        print(result)

main()

def calculate_ways_to_select_problems():
    t = int(input())
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        topics = defaultdict(int)
        difficulties = defaultdict(int)
        
        for _ in range(n):
            a, b = map(int, input().split())
            topics[a] += 1
            difficulties[b] += 1
        
        total_ways = n * (n - 1) * (n - 2) // 6
        
        same_topic = same_difficulty = 0
        for topic in topics.values():
            same_topic += topic * (topic - 1) * (topic - 2) // 6
        for difficulty in difficulties.values():
            same_difficulty += difficulty * (difficulty - 1) * (difficulty - 2) // 6
        
        total_ways -= same_topic + same_difficulty
        
        print(total_ways)

calculate_ways_to_select_problems()

from itertools import combinations

# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of problems
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the topics and difficulties of each problem
    problems = [list(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of ways to select three problems
    count = 0
    
    # Generate all combinations of 3 problems
    problem_combinations = combinations(problems, 3)
    
    # Check each combination if it meets the requirements
    for comb in problem_combinations:
        topics = set()
        difficulties = set()
        for problem in comb:
            topics.add(problem[0])
            difficulties.add(problem[1])
        if len(topics) == 3 or len(difficulties) == 3:
            count += 1
    
    # Output the result for the current testcase
    print(count)

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of problems
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the topics and difficulties of each problem
    problems = [list(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of ways to select three problems
    count = 0
    
    # Generate all combinations of 3 problems

    # Check each combination if it meets the requirements
    for comb in problem_combinations:

        difficulties = set()
        for problem in comb:
            topics.add(problem[0])
            difficulties.add(problem[1])
        if len(topics) == 3 or len(difficulties) == 3:

    # Output the result for the current testcase
    print(count)

prompt:
Monocarp is the coach of the Berland State University programming teams. He decided to create a set of problems for a training session for his teams.

Monocarp has n problems that none of his students have seen yet. The i-th problem has a topic a_i (an integer from 1 to n) and a difficulty b_i (an integer from 1 to n). All problems are different, that is, there are no two tasks that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

Monocarp decided to select exactly 3 problems from n problems for the problemset. The problems should satisfy at least one of two conditions (possibly, both):

  * the topics of all three selected problems are different; 
  * the difficulties of all three selected problems are different. 

Your task is to calculate the number of methods to choose three problems for the problemset. Make sure to consider edge cases where the number of problems n might be small.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 50000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains an integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of problems that Monocarp have.

In the i-th of the following n lines, there are two integers a_i and b_i (1 ≤ a_i, b_i ≤ n) — the topic and the difficulty of the i-th problem.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print the number of ways to select three training problems that meet either of the requirements described in the statement.

Example

Input


2
4
2 4
3 4
2 1
1 3
5
1 5
2 4
3 3
4 2
5 1


Output


3
10

Note

In the first example, you can take the following sets of three problems:

  * problems 1, 2, 4; 
  * problems 1, 3, 4; 
  * problems 2, 3, 4. 



Thus, the number of ways is equal to three.

It is guaranteed that there are no two problems that have the same topic and difficulty at the same time.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.
